subject: Re: [junit] assertTrue(true)
msgSnippet: +1 This is my preference. Dave Thomas teaches the assertTrue(true) but although I ve tried it, I still prefer the empty braces in tests.
messageBody:
+1 This is my preference. Dave Thomas teaches the assertTrue(true) but
although I've tried it, I still prefer the empty braces in tests.

On 5/31/05, Jeff Nielsen <jeff.nielsen@...> wrote:
> I prefer
>
> try {
> articleProvider.findArticleById("foobar");
> fail("Should have thrown NoObjectFoundException");
> } catch(NoObjectFoundException expected) {}
>
> I think this expresses the intent better, and it is the preferred idiom on
> our team. (If checkstyle is forcing you to write extra code, you should fix
> checkstyle.)
>
> Jeff Nielsen
> Digital Focus
> www.digitalfocus.com
>
>
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "haefeleuser" <haefeleuser@...>
> To: <junit@yahoogroups.com>
> Sent: Tuesday, May 31, 2005 10:23 AM
> Subject: [junit] assertTrue(true)
>
>
> > Someone in our team writes his tests like this:
> >
> > try
> > {
> > articleProvider.findArticleById("foobar");
> > }
> > catch(NoObjectFoundException e)
> > {
> > assertTrue(true);
> > }
> >
> > He says the does it because otherwise Checkstyle would complain about
> > the empty catch block.
> >
> > I do it in this manner:
> >
> > try
> > {
> > articleProvider.findArticleById("foobar");
> > }
> > catch(NoObjectFoundException e)
> > {
> > // Its okay since we expect it.
> > }
> >
> > What do you prefer in the case above: assertTrue(true) or inline
> > comment in the catch block?
> >
> >
>
>
>
>

>
>
>
>
>
